newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Gazprom says plans share sale abroad.
newsitem.headline: Gazprom says plans share sale abroad.

text.p: Russia's RAO Gazprom natural gas monopoly said on Wednesday it was preparing to pitch Global and American Depositary Receipts to foreign investors, but declined to say when.
"We really are planning an international share issue," board member Alexander Semenyaka told a news conference. "We are getting ready to do presentations to investors."

He confirmed that Morgan Stanley and Dresdner Bank AG's Kleinwort Benson would lead the issues, but declined to say when paper would be sold. "It will be in tranches, and the first tranche will not be very big," he said.
He said international accountancy firm Price Waterhouse had completed a western-standard audit of Gazprom's books, but declined to state Gazprom's financials.
Eduard Ivanov, head of Gazprom's securities department, said the audit had produced no surprises and that key numbers might be made public at the end of this month.
"Their numbers do not differ significantly from ours," he said, referring to Gazprom's previously stated 1995 pre-tax profit of 17 trillion roubles, about triple the 1994 level.
Gazprom's charter says foreign investors may own no more than nine percent of the company.

London banking sources have said they expect paper to be sold by the end of the year and that the first tranche would be only one or one and a half percent. Semenyaka said in July that receipts would be sold by the end of this month or next month.
Officials said the company's decision last month to tighten the rules under which domestic shareholders can trade paper were in the interests of transparency.
"Simple people, simple shareholders, have a hard time understanding how they can work with our shares," Ivanov said.
Semenyaka said Gazprom was actively buying its shares.

"It (the new rules) reflects the principle of separating the interests of the domestic market from the external one," Semenyaka said. "Work with small shareholders will be significantly increased so they understand how to work with us."
Gazprom's 23.6 billion shares are among Russia's most illiquid stocks.
The company, the world's largest natural gas producer that supplies much of Europe, will use the receipts from the sale to help finance its 4,107 km Yamal-Europe gasline.
Global and American Depositary Receipts are share-lookalikes which allow foreign investors to buy into a company while avoiding domestic settlement problems in emerging markets.
